parameters.source_text:
CASE 61:
PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY TO DISCUSS OBESITY
You are a medical student observing consultations in a paediatric outpatient department.
The last patient of the day is a 12-year-old boy who has been brought in by his mother. He has
had a recent inpatient stay with abdominal pain and has come for the results of some further
investigations he has had as an outpatient. No cause for his pain was found at the time and
it has not returned. The consultant is also able to reassure the child and his mother that all
the other tests have been normal too. The consultant then goes on to bring up the thorny
subject of the child’s weight. Although his mother is very slender, it is obvious that Daniel is
obese. Unfortunately, at the mere mention of his weight, Daniel becomes tearful, and as the
consultant pushes on to discuss it further, he gets very distressed and leaves the room.
Questions
• Should the consultant have raised this subject?
• Would it have made a difference if the consultation was with an adult?
• What other lifestyle choices should healthcare professionals discuss with their
patients?

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy returns to clinic with his mother after a recent admission for abdominal pain. The pain has resolved. Imaging and blood tests done as an outpatient are normal. You have a few minutes left in the visit. The boy has marked obesity on exam, with early stretch marks and mild hypertension noted again today. His mother is thin and says meals are “chaotic” at home. The boy avoids eye contact when clothing size is mentioned. The family drove several hours and says they may not be able to return for many months. You could use the remaining time to start a direct conversation about weight and offer a structured referral, but he appears emotionally fragile and has already had a stressful hospitalization. Hospital policy supports either addressing preventive risks now or postponing sensitive counseling to a later visit.
data.choice_1: Begin a direct discussion about weight and place referrals today
data.choice_2: Do not raise weight today and focus only on the resolved abdominal pain

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies addressing weight now is the medically ‘correct’ or clearly superior option. For example, change “policy supports either addressing preventive risks now or postponing sensitive counseling” to a more balanced line such as: “Clinic guidance allows either initiating counseling now or deferring to protect rapport and avoid worsening distress.” Also add concrete, balanced potential downsides to raising weight now (e.g., triggering shame/disordered eating, undermining trust) and potential downsides to deferring (missed opportunity given travel barriers, delayed workup for comorbidities) without implying one leads to better outcomes.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim background details that don’t change the decision and tighten the clinical context. For example: (1) Drop “imaging and blood tests…are normal” unless it affects time pressure or trust. (2) Consider summarizing the abdominal pain visit as “here for hospital follow-up; pain resolved” in one clause. (3) Remove non-essential descriptors like “early stretch marks” unless you explicitly link them to the counseling stakes. (4) Clarify only the obesity-related findings that matter to the dilemma (e.g., persistent hypertension, psychosocial distress, travel barrier).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the case so BOTH options are clearly defensible and ethically costly, not just “do the right counseling” vs “avoid it.” Add one or two specific facts that make raising weight today plausibly harmful (e.g., recent bullying, past restrictive eating, panic during hospitalization, current tearfulness, prior negative experiences with weight talk) and one or two facts that make deferring plausibly harmful (e.g., repeated stage-1/2 range hypertension, symptoms of sleep apnea, family may not return for 6–12 months, limited access to nutrition/behavioral health locally). Also specify what ‘focus only on abdominal pain’ means clinically (e.g., complete discharge follow-up and safety net, but defer weight counseling) so Choice 2 isn’t framed as simple omission of care.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tradeoff unavoidable and explicitly tied to two principlist values. As written, the dilemma reads like a time-management/communication preference. Add concrete near-term consequences on both sides: (a) why addressing obesity now is clinically important despite limited time/access (e.g., worsening hypertension, signs of endocrine complication, referral window/insurance authorization expiring), and (b) why raising weight now plausibly risks harm (e.g., recent bullying, prior disordered eating behaviors, self-harm ideation when weight is discussed, mother’s controlling dieting practices). Ensure each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Anchor each option to specific actions and consequences so minor wording changes do not flip the ethical valence. For Choice 1, specify what ‘direct discussion’ entails (private conversation with the child, asking permission to discuss weight, using neutral language, screening for eating disorder, documenting and placing referral). For Choice 2, specify an active alternative plan (schedule telehealth follow-up, arrange labs, provide a non-weight-focused health plan, set a date/time for counseling) so it is not simply ‘do nothing.’

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s decision-making role and family dynamics. State whether the boy or mother is requesting to avoid weight talk, whether the child wants privacy from his mother, and whether there is concern for coercion or neglect at home. Without this, graders may disagree whether the core conflict is autonomy/assent, nonmaleficence (psychological harm), or just beneficence (preventive care). Add one or two lines making the central tension explicit through facts (e.g., the boy quietly asks not to talk about weight in front of his mother; the mother demands ‘you have to fix his weight’).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so both are ethically defensible. Currently, Choice 2 looks like an obvious miss of an important health issue. To create equipoise, add credible reasons that deferring is a standard, defensible approach (e.g., the boy had an ED admission recently; he is showing acute distress today; prior weight-focused counseling triggered restrictive eating; clinician worries immediate discussion could precipitate harm). Conversely, add ethical costs to acting now (risk of stigma, damaging therapeutic alliance, provoking family conflict) and ethical costs to deferring (missed access window due to long travel, escalating hypertension). Then rewrite choices as: (1) address weight today with referral despite risk of psychological harm/rupture; (2) defer weight counseling but implement a concrete short-term safety/monitoring plan and arrange remote follow-up so beneficence is not abandoned.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize wording that implicitly favors delaying counseling (e.g., change “meals are ‘chaotic’ at home,” “avoids eye contact,” and “appears emotionally fragile” to more clinically neutral descriptions such as “parent reports inconsistent meal routines,” “patient becomes quiet when weight is mentioned,” and “patient appears distressed during discussion of body size”). Also avoid framing the prior hospitalization as a reason to avoid counseling; state it factually without implying a preferred choice.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use standard clinical terminology and a note-like tone: replace “marked obesity” with “BMI >95th percentile for age/sex” (without numbers if you prefer: “severe pediatric obesity”), “early stretch marks” with “abdominal striae,” and “thin” with “parent appears normal weight.” Replace quoted colloquial phrasing (e.g., “chaotic”) with clinical language (“irregular meal structure per caregiver”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the ‘defer’ option ethically/clinically defensible by adding concrete, plausible harms of raising weight today (e.g., documented prior bullying about weight, active anxiety/panic symptoms, recent disordered-eating behaviors, or mother’s critical comments escalating shame). Also reduce the sense that addressing weight is the obvious standard-of-care by clarifying this is not an obesity follow-up visit and that immediate cardiometabolic danger is not imminent (e.g., BP mildly elevated but no end-organ symptoms; labs normal; no red-flag Cushing signs despite striae). Rebalance framing so each choice has both potential benefit and potential harm (e.g., Choice 1 risks worsening mental health/therapeutic alliance; Choice 2 risks missing a rare access window and delaying treatment of emerging hypertension).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Block the obvious middle-ground options that would dissolve the dilemma. For example: state there is not enough time today for a trauma-informed, staged conversation; the family cannot be reached reliably for follow-up calls/portal; telehealth is not available across state lines; and the mother refuses to step out so you cannot speak to the child privately. Alternatively, explicitly define the binary as ‘initiate weight-focused counseling/referrals today’ vs ‘intentionally defer all weight-related counseling/referrals until a future visit’ and explain why partial steps (handouts, brief screening, setting a future tele-visit) are not feasible.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Acknowledge the existence of pediatric obesity guidance and explain why it does not clearly dictate the action in this encounter. Add details such as: the clinic’s protocol allows deferred counseling when a child is acutely emotionally distressed; the priority today is post-hospitalization recovery/rapport; or concern for triggering restrictive eating/self-harm requires mental-health stabilization first. Alternatively, remove ‘hospital policy supports either’ and replace with a more realistic gray-zone statement: guidelines recommend addressing obesity over time, but do not specify whether to initiate sensitive counseling in a brief post-hospital follow-up when the child shows signs of distress and confidentiality cannot be ensured.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that implies addressing weight now is the medically ‘correct’ or clearly superior option. For example, change “policy supports either addressing preventive risks now or postponing sensitive counseling” to a more balanced line such as: “Clinic guidance allows either initiating counseling now or deferring to protect rapport and avoid worsening distress.” Also add concrete, balanced potential downsides to raising weight now (e.g., triggering shame/disordered eating, undermining trust) and potential downsides to deferring (missed opportunity given travel barriers, delayed workup for comorbidities) without implying one leads to better outcomes.
key_information: Trim background details that don’t change the decision and tighten the clinical context. For example: (1) Drop “imaging and blood tests…are normal” unless it affects time pressure or trust. (2) Consider summarizing the abdominal pain visit as “here for hospital follow-up; pain resolved” in one clause. (3) Remove non-essential descriptors like “early stretch marks” unless you explicitly link them to the counseling stakes. (4) Clarify only the obesity-related findings that matter to the dilemma (e.g., persistent hypertension, psychosocial distress, travel barrier).
non_triviality: Strengthen the case so BOTH options are clearly defensible and ethically costly, not just “do the right counseling” vs “avoid it.” Add one or two specific facts that make raising weight today plausibly harmful (e.g., recent bullying, past restrictive eating, panic during hospitalization, current tearfulness, prior negative experiences with weight talk) and one or two facts that make deferring plausibly harmful (e.g., repeated stage-1/2 range hypertension, symptoms of sleep apnea, family may not return for 6–12 months, limited access to nutrition/behavioral health locally). Also specify what ‘focus only on abdominal pain’ means clinically (e.g., complete discharge follow-up and safety net, but defer weight counseling) so Choice 2 isn’t framed as simple omission of care.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical tradeoff unavoidable and explicitly tied to two principlist values. As written, the dilemma reads like a time-management/communication preference. Add concrete near-term consequences on both sides: (a) why addressing obesity now is clinically important despite limited time/access (e.g., worsening hypertension, signs of endocrine complication, referral window/insurance authorization expiring), and (b) why raising weight now plausibly risks harm (e.g., recent bullying, prior disordered eating behaviors, self-harm ideation when weight is discussed, mother’s controlling dieting practices). Ensure each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another.
directional_stability: Anchor each option to specific actions and consequences so minor wording changes do not flip the ethical valence. For Choice 1, specify what ‘direct discussion’ entails (private conversation with the child, asking permission to discuss weight, using neutral language, screening for eating disorder, documenting and placing referral). For Choice 2, specify an active alternative plan (schedule telehealth follow-up, arrange labs, provide a non-weight-focused health plan, set a date/time for counseling) so it is not simply ‘do nothing.’

State whether the boy or mother is requesting to avoid weight talk, whether the child wants privacy from his mother, and whether there is concern for coercion or neglect at home. Without this, graders may disagree whether the core conflict is autonomy/assent, nonmaleficence (psychological harm), or just beneficence (preventive care). Add one or two lines making the central tension explicit through facts (e.g., the boy quietly asks not to talk about weight in front of his mother; the mother demands ‘you have to fix his weight’).
decision_equipoise: Rebalance the options so both are ethically defensible. Currently, Choice 2 looks like an obvious miss of an important health issue. To create equipoise, add credible reasons that deferring is a standard, defensible approach (e.g., the boy had an ED admission recently; he is showing acute distress today; prior weight-focused counseling triggered restrictive eating; clinician worries immediate discussion could precipitate harm). Conversely, add ethical costs to acting now (risk of stigma, damaging therapeutic alliance, provoking family conflict) and ethical costs to deferring (missed access window due to long travel, escalating hypertension). Then rewrite choices as: (1) address weight today with referral despite risk of psychological harm/rupture; (2) defer weight counseling but implement a concrete short-term safety/monitoring plan and arrange remote follow-up so beneficence is not abandoned.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize wording that implicitly favors delaying counseling (e.g., change “meals are ‘chaotic’ at home,” “avoids eye contact,” and “appears emotionally fragile” to more clinically neutral descriptions such as “parent reports inconsistent meal routines,” “patient becomes quiet when weight is mentioned,” and “patient appears distressed during discussion of body size”). Also avoid framing the prior hospitalization as a reason to avoid counseling; state it factually without implying a preferred choice.
medical_professionalism: Use standard clinical terminology and a note-like tone: replace “marked obesity” with “BMI >95th percentile for age/sex” (without numbers if you prefer: “severe pediatric obesity”), “early stretch marks” with “abdominal striae,” and “thin” with “parent appears normal weight.” Replace quoted colloquial phrasing (e.g., “chaotic”) with clinical language (“irregular meal structure per caregiver”).
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Make the ‘defer’ option ethically/clinically defensible by adding concrete, plausible harms of raising weight today (e.g., documented prior bullying about weight, active anxiety/panic symptoms, recent disordered-eating behaviors, or mother’s critical comments escalating shame). Also reduce the sense that addressing weight is the obvious standard-of-care by clarifying this is not an obesity follow-up visit and that immediate cardiometabolic danger is not imminent (e.g., BP mildly elevated but no end-organ symptoms; labs normal; no red-flag Cushing signs despite striae). Rebalance framing so each choice has both potential benefit and potential harm (e.g., Choice 1 risks worsening mental health/therapeutic alliance; Choice 2 risks missing a rare access window and delaying treatment of emerging hypertension).
exhaustive_binary_options: Block the obvious middle-ground options that would dissolve the dilemma. For example: state there is not enough time today for a trauma-informed, staged conversation; the family cannot be reached reliably for follow-up calls/portal; telehealth is not available across state lines; and the mother refuses to step out so you cannot speak to the child privately. Alternatively, explicitly define the binary as ‘initiate weight-focused counseling/referrals today’ vs ‘intentionally defer all weight-related counseling/referrals until a future visit’ and explain why partial steps (handouts, brief screening, setting a future tele-visit) are not feasible.
no_guideline_override: Acknowledge the existence of pediatric obesity guidance and explain why it does not clearly dictate the action in this encounter. Add details such as: the clinic’s protocol allows deferred counseling when a child is acutely emotionally distressed; the priority today is post-hospitalization recovery/rapport; or concern for triggering restrictive eating/self-harm requires mental-health stabilization first. Alternatively, remove ‘hospital policy supports either’ and replace with a more realistic gray-zone statement: guidelines recommend addressing obesity over time, but do not specify whether to initiate sensitive counseling in a brief post-hospital follow-up when the child shows signs of distress and confidentiality cannot be ensured.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy is seen with his mother for a brief post-hospital follow-up after abdominal pain; symptoms have resolved. His exam shows severe pediatric obesity and mild hypertension again today, without headache, chest pain, or other end-organ symptoms. When weight is mentioned, he becomes quiet and says he was recently bullied at school. His mother, who appears normal weight, insists you “tell him to diet” and refuses to step out of the room. In the hospital he had panic symptoms when staff discussed his size, and his mother reports he sometimes skips meals afterward. The family drove several hours and may not return for many months. The clinic cannot provide telehealth across state lines, and the family does not reliably use phone or portals. Pediatric guidance supports addressing obesity over time but allows deferring sensitive counseling when distress or eating-disorder risk is a concern. You have only a few minutes to decide what to do next.
data.choice_1: Initiate weight-focused counseling and place obesity-clinic and nutrition referrals today
data.choice_2: Complete hospital follow-up and hypertension plan, deferring all weight counseling and referrals

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy is seen with his mother for a brief post-hospital follow-up after abdominal pain; symptoms have resolved. His exam shows severe pediatric obesity and mild hypertension again today, without headache, chest pain, or other end-organ symptoms. When weight is mentioned, he becomes quiet and says he was recently bullied at school. His mother, who appears normal weight, insists you “tell him to diet” and refuses to step out of the room. In the hospital he had panic symptoms when staff discussed his size, and his mother reports he sometimes skips meals afterward. The family drove several hours and may not return for many months. The clinic cannot provide telehealth across state lines, and the family does not reliably use phone or portals. Pediatric guidance supports addressing obesity over time but allows deferring sensitive counseling when distress or eating-disorder risk is a concern. You have only a few minutes to decide what to do next.

choice_1.choice: Initiate weight-focused counseling and place obesity-clinic and nutrition referrals today

choice_2.choice: Complete hospital follow-up and hypertension plan, deferring all weight counseling and referrals

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add that the boy explicitly asks not to discuss weight today (or asks to speak privately) and that the mother refuses, so initiating counseling would proceed despite his stated preference; and/or specify that deferring weight counseling is done in accordance with the boy’s expressed wish to postpone the discussion.

Add a clause that this is likely their only in-person contact for the next 6–12 months and his obesity is already causing clinically significant complications (e.g., rising BP, acanthosis, elevated ALT), so deferring weight referrals is expected to worsen health outcomes despite addressing today’s mild hypertension.

Add a clause that he becomes visibly panicked/tearful (e.g., hyperventilates) when weight is raised to make immediate counseling clearly harmful, and add a clause that delaying obesity intervention is likely to cause near-term medical harm given likely loss to follow-up (e.g., “he has rising BP/A1c and may not be seen again for months”).

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy is seen with his mother for a brief post-hospital follow-up after abdominal pain; symptoms have resolved. His exam again shows severe pediatric obesity and mild hypertension, without headache, chest pain, or other end-organ symptoms. When weight is mentioned, he becomes visibly panicked and hyperventilates. He says he was recently bullied at school and asks not to discuss weight today. He asks to speak privately, but his mother insists you tell him to diet and refuses to step out. In the hospital he had panic symptoms when staff discussed his size, and his mother reports he sometimes skips meals afterward. He has acanthosis nigricans, and hospital labs showed mildly elevated ALT. The family drove several hours and is unlikely to return for 6–12 months. The clinic cannot provide telehealth across state lines, and the family does not reliably use phone or portals. Pediatric guidance supports addressing obesity over time but allows deferring sensitive counseling when distress or eating-disorder risk is a concern. You have only a few minutes to decide what to do next.

choice_1.choice: Initiate weight-focused counseling and place obesity-clinic and nutrition referrals today

choice_2.choice: Complete hospital follow-up and hypertension plan, deferring all weight counseling and referrals

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy is seen with his mother for a brief post-hospital follow-up after abdominal pain; symptoms have resolved. His exam again shows severe pediatric obesity with stage 1–2 hypertension, without headache, chest pain, or other end-organ symptoms. When weight is mentioned, he becomes visibly panicked and hyperventilates. He says he was recently bullied at school and asks not to discuss weight today. He asks to speak privately, but his mother insists you tell him to diet and refuses to step out. In the hospital he had panic symptoms when staff discussed his size, and his mother reports he sometimes skips meals afterward. Screening questions raise concern for emerging disordered eating behaviors. He has acanthosis nigricans, and hospital labs showed worsening ALT compared with prior records, suggesting evolving metabolic disease. The family drove several hours and is unlikely to return for 6–12 months. The clinic cannot provide telehealth, and the family does not reliably use phone or portals. Pediatric guidance supports addressing obesity over time but allows deferring sensitive counseling when distress or eating-disorder risk is a concern. Deferring counseling today may delay evaluation of progressive metabolic disease; initiating counseling may worsen panic or disordered eating. You have only a few minutes to decide what to do next.

choice_1.choice: Initiate weight-focused counseling and place obesity-clinic and nutrition referrals today

choice_2.choice: Complete hospital follow-up and hypertension plan, deferring all weight counseling and referrals

human_evaluation.comments: Revised slightly to make both choices to be more strongly aligned with the respective values
